title: 113_hr3583
content: The Act may be cited as the "Malala Yousafzai Scholarship Act". Malala Yousafzai was targeted by the Taliban for advocating women's education, leading to her being shot in the head in 2012. Despite objections, she continued to push for education through writing and speeches, including one at the United Nations in 2013. Malala Yousafzai advocates for education, stating that it is the most powerful weapon to change the world. Pakistan faces challenges with a large number of out-of-school children, especially in rural areas. Women's education benefits society by improving health, increasing income, and providing better care for children. Education is crucial for improving the well-being of individuals and lifting households out of poverty. According to the United Nations, education can significantly increase women's earnings, with highly literate women in Pakistan earning 95% more than those with no literacy skills. Secretary of State Hillary Clinton emphasized the importance of education for all citizens, especially girls and women, as it leads to better health and opportunities for families to flourish. The United States provides critical foreign assistance to Pakistan's education sector through the Merit and Needs-Based Scholarship Program, which awards scholarships to academically talented, financially needy Pakistani students, with 50% going to women. The United States provides foreign assistance to Pakistan's education sector through scholarships, with 50% allocated to women. The United Nations declared July 12, 2013, as "Malala Day" in support of Malala's advocacy for women's education. Malala Yousafzai received the Nobel Peace Prize in 2014 for her work promoting children's right to education. The Malala Fund for Girls' Education was launched in 2012 to improve girls' access to education globally. Over 1,000,000 people have supported the United Nations Special Envoy for Global Education. The United Nations Special Envoy for Global Education petitioned the Government of Pakistan to enroll every boy and girl in primary school. Pakistani civil society organizations collected 2,000,000 signatures in support of Malala's cause. Engagement with Pakistani diaspora communities in the United States is crucial for promoting greater access to education for women and girls in Pakistan. Congress emphasizes the importance of education for all individuals, regardless of gender, and supports educational initiatives in Pakistan. Recipients of scholarships are encouraged to give back to their communities. The Department of State and USAID are urged to continue supporting education programs in Pakistan, especially for women. The USAID Administrator must allocate at least 50% of scholarships to women under the Merit and Needs-Based Scholarship Program for the years 2014 through 2016. Scholarships must adhere to existing eligibility criteria and cover various disciplines to enhance graduates' employability. Efforts should be made to ensure that 50% of scholarships are awarded. The USAID Administrator aims to allocate 50% of scholarships to Pakistani women under the Program. Efforts will be made to consult and leverage investments from the Pakistani private sector and diaspora communities in the US to enhance education programs in Pakistan. SEC. 5. ANNUAL CONGRESSIONAL BRIEFING. The USAID Administrator will brief congressional committees annually for 3 years on the implementation of section 4, including details on scholarships awarded, disciplines of study, and dropout rates. The USAID Administrator will provide annual briefings to congressional committees on the implementation of section 4, including scholarship recipients who dropped out of school voluntarily or involuntarily for not meeting program requirements, and those who left due to retaliation for seeking an education. The House of Representatives passed the bill on November 19, 2014. Karen L. Haas is the Clerk.
